name: Procrastination
meaning: The action of delaying or postponing something
example: Ram procrastinated his homework and missed the date of submission

name: Broadly
meaning: In general and without considering minor details.
example: Broadly speaking, I agree with you

name: Comprehensive
meaning: Covering completely & including everything that is necessary
example: We offer you a comprehensive training in all aspects of the business

name: Dire
example: Misuse of drugs can have dire consequences

name: Endeavour
meaning: An attempt to achieve a goal
example: An endeavour to reduce serious injury

name: Incorporate
meaning: To include or integrate into something that’s already existing
example: The area was successfully incorporated as part of the city

name: Solvent
meaning: Having enough money to pay all the money that is owed to other people
example: Many insurance companies are under pressure to increase premiums to stay solvent

name: Subsume
meaning: To include something or someone as part of a larger group
example: Soldiers from many different countries have been subsumed into the United Nations peace-keeping force

name: Unpropitious
meaning: Not favorable or Not likely to have or produce a good result
example: The candidate’s unpropitious speak is unlikely to win him any votes

name: Recession
meaning: A period of temporary economic decline during which trade and industrial activity are reduced
example: The country is in the depths of a recession

name: Dearth
meaning: A scarcity or lack of something
example: There is a dearth of evidence

name: Inevitable
example: War was inevitable

name: Venture
example: We ventured out into the woods

name: Contemporary
example: Was he a contemporary of Shakespeare's?

name: Subtle
meaning: So small or precise as to be difficult to analyse or describe
example: There is a subtle difference between these two plans

name: Impregnable
meaning: unable to be captured or broken into
example: The fortress is impregnable

name: Insidious
meaning: Proceeding in a gradual, subtle way, but with very harmful effects
example: Sexual harassment is a serious and insidious problem

name: Cataclysm
example: A cataclysmic earthquake

name: Corroborate
example: The theory has been corroborated by recent studies

name: Juxtapose
meaning: To place two concepts or objects next to or near each other, thereby highlighting their differences and similarities
example: Juxtapose two opposing views about the phenomenon

name: Abate
example: NASA announced that it would delay the launch of the manned spacecraft until the radiation from the solar flares abated

name: Apportioned
example: In United states, fandom is evenly apportioned among different sports

name: Abscond
example: Paul barber absconded with 2 million dollars

name: Delusion
meaning: False belief or perception that is not based on reality or evidence
example: John's delusion that he is a superhero often leads him to take unnecessary risks and put himself in danger

name: Cognitive
meaning: It relates to the ability to understand and process information
example: The cognitive abilities of children develop rapidly during the first few years of life

name: Dementia
meaning: It is used to describe a decline in cognitive function, such as memory loss, language difficulties, and impaired judgment
example: My grandmother suffers from dementia and has trouble remembering who her family members are

name: Catastrophe
meaning: It refers to a sudden and widespread disaster or misfortune that causes great damage or suffering
example: The earthquake that struck the city last night was a catastrophic event that destroyed many buildings and claimed numerous lives

name: Hysteria
meaning: It refers to a state of uncontrollable emotion, often characterized by anxiety, fear, or panic
example: The news of the virus outbreak caused widespread hysteria, with people rushing to buy supplies and stock up on food

name: Paradox
meaning: A statement that seems to go against common sense but may still be true
example: The enemy of my enemy is my friend

name: Propaganda
meaning: It refers to information, ideas, or opinions that are deliberately spread in order to influence public
example: The film was criticized for being nothing more than a piece of propaganda, promoting an ideology without an accuracy

name: Seldom
meaning: It implies that something happens only on rare occasions or is not a common occurrence
example: Despite his busy schedule, Jack seldom misses a workout at the gym

name: Susceptible
meaning: It means being easily influenced or affected by something
example: Children are more susceptible to illnesses than adults because their immune systems are not fully developed

name: Irksome
meaning: It means annoying, irritating, or causing discomfort
example: The irksome smell of cigarette smoke in the restaurant ruined our dining experience

name: Gratify
meaning: It means to please or satisfy someone by fulfilling their desires, wishes or expectations
example: The teacher was gratified by the students' excellent performance in the final exams

name: Obscure
meaning: It means something that is difficult to understand, unclear, or not well known
example: The movie was criticized heavily by critics for its obscure plot and confusing narrative structure

name: Morbid
meaning: It refers to something that is related to or characteristic of disease, illness, death, or unpleasant events
example: The old abandoned hospital had a morbid atmosphere that sent shivers down my spine

name: Daunting
meaning: It means something that appears difficult, challenging, or intimidating, to the point of making someone feel discouraged or overwhelmed
example: The amount of work required to complete the project was daunting, but they managed to finish it on time

name: Intimidate
meaning: It means to make someone feel afraid
example: The witness was afraid to testify in court because she had been intimidated by the defendant's supporters

name: Trivial
meaning: It means something that is unimportant, or insignificant
example: The teacher reminded the students not to waste time on trivial details but to focus on the main ideas

name: Deceptive
meaning: It refers to something that is misleading or lie
example: The advertisement was found to be deceptive, as it exaggerated the benefits of the product

name: Impediment
meaning: It refers to obstacles or barriers that prevent or hinder progress or movement
example: The lack of funding was the biggest impediment to the success of the project

name: Counterfeit
example: The cops caught 2 million dollars of counterfeit currency from Paul Barber

name: Exploit
meaning: To take advantage of something in an unfair way, or to make use of a resource or opportunity skilfully
example: The athlete was able to exploit the opponent's weaknesses to win the match

name: Woo
meaning: Efforts to impress or try to gain the favor, affection, or support of someone
example: The politician tried to woo voters with promises of tax cuts and job creation

name: Candid
example: The candidate's answers during the interview were candid

name: Patent
example: It was patent to everyone that she was lying

name: Painstaking
meaning: It describes something that is done with great care, effort, and attention
example: The artist's masterpiece was the product of years of painstaking effort and dedication

name: Discrepancy
meaning: Difference or inconsistency between two or more things
example: There was a discrepancy between the witness's testimony and the physical evidence found at the crime scene

name: Improbable
meaning: It describes something that is unlikely or not probable to happen or be true
example: It seems improbable that the small startup company will be able to compete with the industry giants

name: Arcane
example: The computer program relied on an arcane set of commands that only a few understands

name: Erstwhile
example: The company's erstwhile CEO had retired years ago and was now living a quiet life on a farm

name: Surrogate
example: The team's captain was injured during the game, so a surrogate was brought in to take his place

name: Facetious
meaning: Treating serious issues with inappropriate humor or flippant sarcasm
example: The comedian made a facetious remark about the pandemic during his stand-up routine, which some audience members found insensitive

name: Pervasive
example: The pervasive use of plastic has led to environmental pollution on a global scale

name: Cosmopolitan
meaning: Sophisticated or containing people and things from many different parts of the world
example: Immigration transformed the city into a cosmopolitan metropolis

name: Abdicate
meaning: To give up a position, right, or power
example: The king decided to abdicate and pass the crown to her son

name: Aberrant
meaning: Deviating from what's normal or expected
example: The scientist noticed an aberrant result in the experiment

name: Abeyance
example: The project was put in abeyance until the funding is received

name: Abjure
example: The former gang member decided to abjure his affiliation and start a new life

name: Introvert
meaning: A person who enjoys time alone
example: She is an introvert and prefers spending her weekends reading at home rather than going out with friends

name: Hypocrisy
meaning: It involves saying or doing one thing but believing or doing the opposite
example: The CEO's public statements about social responsibility were exposed as hypocrisy when found out that the company had been engaging in unethical business practices

name: Appetite
meaning: A desire for food or drinks
example: The doctor advised her to eat smaller portions to help control her appetite and lose weight

name: Obsolete
meaning: Something that is no longer in use, or is outdated
example: The old computer that I found in my garage is completely obsolete and can't even run modern software

name: Mediocre
meaning: Something that is average or of only moderate quality, neither very good nor very bad
example: The food at the restaurant was mediocre; it wasn't terrible, but it also wasn't amazing

name: Deemed
meaning: To be judged or considered in a particular way
example: The proposal was deemed to be too risky and was rejected by the board

name: Abject
example: The team's performance was abject, with no signs of improvement throughout the game

name: Abscission
meaning: The act of cutting, or natural separation of leaves from plants
example: The abscission of the leaves from the trees in autumn is a beautiful natural process

name: Abstinence
example: His abstinence from junk food and soda helped him lose weight

name: Abstemious
meaning: Who follows moderate appetite, or a self-disciplined life style
example: Despite being at a party, she remained abstemious and only drank water

name: Pseudo
example: The internet is full of pseudo-scientific claims that have no basis in reality

name: Atrocity
example: The government was accused of committing atrocities against its own people, including torture and extrajudicial killings

name: Anomaly
meaning: Something that deviates from what is expected, or normal
example: The security team detected an anomaly in the network traffic that indicated a potential cyberattack

name: Genocide
meaning: Deliberately killing of a large number of people from a particular nation or group with the aim of destroying that nation or group
example: The survivors of the genocide bravely shared their stories in order to prevent it from happening again

name: Lucid
meaning: Something that is clear and easy to understand
example: The teacher's explanations were so lucid that the students could easily grasp the concepts

name: Prodigal
meaning: Refers to a person who is wasteful or reckless with their resources
example: The company's prodigal spending habits led to its eventual bankruptcy

name: Opaque
meaning: Something that is difficult to understand
example: The scientist's explanation of the concept was so opaque that even her colleagues had trouble following it

name: abysmal
example: The team's performance in the last game was abysmal; they lost by a score of 10-0

name: accretion
meaning: A growth, or accumulation of something over time (the context is more of Scientific)
example: The accretion of dust and gas particles over millions of years eventually formed the planets in our solar system

name: accrue
meaning: A growth, or accumulation of something over time (the context is more of Financial)
example: The interest on my savings account accrues at a rate of 2% per year

name: adamant
example: Despite his parents' objections, John remained adamant that he would pursue a career in the arts

name: adjunct
example: Yoga can be an effective adjunct therapy for reducing stress and anxiety

name: admonish
example: The teacher admonished the student for talking during class

name: adulterate
example: The food company was fined for adulterating their products with cheap fillers

name: aesthetic
example: The artist's work was praised for its originality and its strong sense of aesthetics

name: affinity
example: I have a strong affinity for animals and love spending time with my pets

name: aggrandize
meaning: To make larger or greater; Exaggerating
example: The politician's speeches were filled with attempts to aggrandize himself and his accomplishments

name: aggregate
meaning: Collecting different elements into a single entity
example: The aggregate total of the donations raised for the charity was $100,000

name: alacrity
meaning: Cheerful readiness or willingness to do something
example: She responded to the invitation with alacrity, eager to attend the party

name: alchemy
example: The artist's use of color and texture in her paintings is a form of alchemy, transforming raw materials into works of art

name: allay
example: The doctor's reassurances helped allay the patient's fears about the upcoming surgery

name: alleviate
meaning: To reduce or relieve the severity or intensity of something
example: The pain medication helped to alleviate her chronic back pain

name: alloy
meaning: Mixture of two or more metals
example: Titanium alloys are commonly used in aerospace and medical applications for their strength and corrosion resistance

name: allure
example: The high salary offered by the company was an allure for many job seekers

name: amalgamate
meaning: To combine two or more things to a single unit
example: The two companies decided to amalgamate in order to increase their market share

name: ambiguous
meaning: Unclear or open to different interpretations
example: The message in the novel was intentionally ambiguous, leaving the reader to draw their own conclusions

name: amiable
meaning: A person who is friendly, pleasant, and easy to get along with
example: The salesperson was so amiable and charming that I couldn't resist buying the product she was selling

name: anachronism
meaning: Something that is old-fashioned or belonging to a different era
example: The use of a typewriter in a modern office would be considered an anachronism

name: analogous
meaning: Something that is similar or comparable in certain respects, but not identical
example: The wings of a bat are analogous to the wings of a bird, as they both serve the purpose of flight, but are structurally different

name: archaic
meaning: Something that is old-fashioned, outdated, or no longer in use
example: The archaic farming practices of the past are no longer sustainable in the modern world

name: audacity
example: Despite the risks involved, the group of activists showed incredible audacity in standing up to the corrupt government and demanding change

name: autonomous
example: The car has autonomous features that allow it to drive itself on the highway

name: belittle
meaning: To make someone or something seem unimportant, insignificant, or inferior
example: The coach belittled the player in front of the entire team, causing him to lose confidence and motivation

name: censor
meaning: To examine and suppress or remove parts of something that is considered objectionable or offensive
example: The government censored the news report to remove any criticism of their policies

name: chauvinism
meaning: Excessive patriotism, or belief in the superiority of one's own group or gender
example: His chauvinistic attitude towards women was seen as offensive and outdated

name: cohesive
example: The team worked together so well that their play was incredibly cohesive, making it difficult for their opponents to break through their defense

name: complementary
meaning: Something that completes or enhances something else
example: The new software is complementary to the existing system, providing additional functionality and ease of use

name: constraint
example: The budget constraints meant that we had to cut back on staff and resources

name: delegate
meaning: To entrust or assign a task, responsibility, or authority to someone else
example: The manager delegated the task of organizing the company picnic to a team of employees

name: diligent
meaning: Someone who is hardworking, persistent, and careful in their work or duties
example: The student was diligent in her studies, and spent many hours each day working on her assignments and preparing for exams

name: egotist
meaning: Who is excessively self-centered and focused on themselves, and never show consideration for others
example: The CEO was known for his egotism, taking credit for the company's successes and blaming others for its failures

name: embellish
meaning: To decorate or enhance something by adding additional details or feature
example: The politician was accused of embellishing his record to make himself appear more qualified for the job

name: embryonic
example: The new technology is still in its embryonic stage, and it will take years of research and development before it can be used

name: extrapolate
meaning: Making predictions or drawing conclusions based on the available evidence
example: Based on the current trends, we can extrapolate that sales will continue to increase over the next quarter

name: fatigue
meaning: Extreme tiredness resulting from mental or physical exertion or illness
example: After running a marathon, he felt a deep sense of fatigue in his muscles and bones

name: hectic
meaning: Very busy and filled with activity
example: The office was always hectic during the end of the financial year

name: irrefutable
example: The DNA evidence was irrefutable proof of the suspect's guilt in the crime

name: jovial
example: The family enjoyed a jovial dinner together, sharing stories and jokes

name: laborious
meaning: Something that requires a lot of effort, time, or work to be completed
example: The construction of the building was a laborious process that took several years to complete

name: lethargic
meaning: Laziness, lack of energy, or weary
example: After staying up all night studying, she felt lethargic and could barely keep her eyes open

name: malleable
meaning: Something that can be easily shaped or molded without breaking or cracking
example: The candidate's views on certain issues appeared to be malleable, changing depending on the audience

name: melancholy
meaning: A feeling of sadness or depression
example: The music had a melancholy tone, evoking feelings of sadness and nostalgia

name: mesmerise
example: The singer's performance was so captivating that it mesmerized the audience

name: mundane
meaning: Very ordinary and therefore not interesting
example: The office worker's mundane job involved a lot of paperwork and data entry

name: obese
example: The doctor advised the patient to lose weight since being obese increases the risk of developing various health issues

name: paragon
meaning: A person or thing that is considered a model or perfect example
example: He was a paragon of honesty, and was admired by everyone who knew him

name: pinnacle
meaning: The highest point of something, such as a mountain, a career, or an achievement
example: Winning an Academy Award is often seen as the pinnacle of an actor's career

name: pretentious
meaning: Trying too hard to impress others and suggests a lack of authenticity or sincerity
example: He was often mocked for his pretentious clothing and accessories, which he wore in an attempt to show off his wealth and status

name: retract
meaning: To withdraw, cancel, or take back
example: The politician was forced to retract his statement after it was proven to be false

name: robust
meaning: Strong and healthy, or sturdy and durable
example: The athlete's robust physique was a result of years of training and exercise

name: serene
example: The ocean was calm and serene, with the sun setting behind the horizon and casting a warm glow over the water

name: sluggish
meaning: Something that moves or operates slowly or with little energy
example: She felt sluggish and unmotivated after eating a heavy meal

name: stipend
meaning: A fixed amount of money that is paid regularly to someone, typically as a salary or allowance
example: Graduate students often receive a stipend to cover tuition and living expenses while they pursue their studies

name: summit
meaning: The highest point or peak of a mountain, or a meeting between leaders or officials of different countries or organizations
example: The climbers finally reached the summit of Mount Everest after weeks of climbing

name: tarnish
example: The scandal tarnished his reputation

name: tenacious
example: Despite facing numerous setbacks and obstacles, the athlete remained tenacious and refused to give up on his dream of winning the gold medal

name: unprecedented
meaning: Something that is completely new, unexpected, or groundbreaking
example: The COVID-19 pandemic has brought unprecedented challenges to the healthcare system and the global economy

name: abstain
meaning: Withhold, or deliberately choose not to do something
example: He decided to abstain from eating dessert to maintain a healthier diet

name: antipathy
meaning: A strong dislike, towards someone or something
example: There was an immediate antipathy between the two rival teams on the field

name: apathy
meaning: Indifference or lack of interest about something
example: The student's apathy towards studying resulted in poor academic performance

name: apogee
example: The spacecraft reached its apogee and began to descend back towards Earth

name: appease
meaning: To satisfy, or calm someone or a situation by meeting their demands
example: He bought her favorite flowers to appease her after an argument

name: arbitrary
meaning: A choice, action, or decision is based on personal preference
example: The judge's ruling appeared to be arbitrary, lacking a solid legal basis or logical justification

name: artful
example: He devised an artful plan to exploit his opponents

name: autocratic
meaning: A form of government or leadership in which a single person or group has absolute power and control over others; Tyrannical
example: In an autocratic government, the ruling party has complete control over the legislative, executive, and judicial branches of government

name: avert
meaning: To prevent or avoid something undesirable from happening
example: She managed to avert a car accident by changing direction at the last moment

name: banish
meaning: To send someone or something away or to exile them; Getting rid of something or eliminating it completely
example: The king decided to banish the traitor from the kingdom forever

name: bleak
meaning: Hopelessness (context:- Situation); Empty or not attractive (context- Place)
example: The future looked bleak for the company, with declining sales and mounting debt

name: bolster
meaning: To support, strengthen, or reinforce something or someone
example: The government introduced new policies to bolster the economy and promote job growth

name: chivalrous
meaning: Very polite and kind toward women
example: The chivalrous gentleman offered his umbrella to the woman caught in the rain

name: colossal
example: The concert attracted a colossal crowd

name: contentious
meaning: Something that is likely to cause disagreement or argument
example: The divorce proceedings became increasingly contentious, with both parties fighting over custody of their children and their shared assets

name: crestfallen
meaning: A state of extreme disappointment, or sadness
example: After receiving the rejection letter, she felt crestfallen, as she had worked so hard on the application

name: crystallize
meaning: The process of making something clear, definite, or well-defined
example: As the temperature dropped, the water molecules began to crystallize, forming beautiful ice crystals

name: decry
meaning: Publicly condemn or express strong disapproval of someone or something
example: The coach decryed the behavior of his players, who had shown a lack of sportsmanship during the game

name: deify
meaning: Worship or regard as a god
example: People deified the emperor

name: deliberate
meaning: To think about or discuss something very carefully
example: She made a deliberate decision to take a year off from work to travel and explore new places

name: detrimental
meaning: Something that causes harm, damage, or has a negative impact on someone or something
example: Smoking tobacco can be detrimental to your health.

name: discreet
meaning: Someone or something that is careful, cautious, and maintains confidentiality or secrecy
example: As a lawyer, she was always discreet with her clients' confidential information

name: dishearten
meaning: It describes the act of discouraging or demoralising someone
example: The negative feedback from the audience disheartened the young actress, but she resolved to work harder and prove her talent

name: eccentric
meaning: Unconventional, Peculiar, or deviates from the usual or expected norms or behaviours
example: Despite his eccentric behavior, the old lady was loved and respected by the neighborhood for her kindness

name: empathy
meaning: The ability to understand and share the feelings of another
example: She displayed empathy by listening attentively to her friend's struggles and offering words of support

name: enthrall
meaning: To captivate or fascinate someone, to hold their attention or interest completely
example: The audience was completely enthralled by the magician's performance, as he made objects disappear and reappear before their very eyes

name: equitable
example: The company implemented an equitable salary structure to ensure that all employees are fairly compensated for their work

name: equivocal
example: The statement made by the suspect during interrogation was equivocal, requiring further investigation to uncover the truth

name: euphoria
meaning: A state of intense happiness, excitement, or joy
example: Winning the championship filled the team with euphoria

name: exemplar
example: The company's success story has become an exemplar for aspiring entrepreneurs in the industry

name: futile
meaning: Incapable of producing results; Pointlessness, or uselessness
example: The workers' strike was deemed futile as the company remained unwilling to negotiate

name: impeccable
example: Her presentation was delivered with impeccable timing and clarity

name: industrious
example: She is an industrious student who consistently completes assignments ahead of time

name: inferred
meaning: To draw a conclusion or make an assumption based on the information
example: Based on the tone of her voice, I inferred that she was upset about something

name: jargon
meaning: Special words or expressions used by a profession or group that are difficult for others to understand
example: During the meeting, the engineers discussed their project using technical jargon that was unfamiliar to the marketing team

name: meander
example: The conversation meandered from politics to sports to movies, covering a wide range of topics

name: meteoric
meaning: To describe a rapid, impressive, or dramatic rise or increase in something
example: The company experienced meteoric growth, expanding its operations globally within a short span of time

name: misconstrue
meaning: To interpret, understand, or explain something incorrectly or inaccurately
example: The comedian's joke was misconstrued as offensive, causing controversy and backlash

name: modicum
example: She showed a modicum of respect for her opponent, even though they were competing against each other

name: oblique
example: She made an oblique reference to the incident without directly addressing it

name: pastoral
example: The church was set in a pastoral location, surrounded by rolling hills and fields of wildflowers

name: prevail
example: In a close race, the candidate with the most votes will prevail and win the election

name: pristine
meaning: It conveys a sense of purity, cleanliness, and freshness
example: The newly built house had pristine white walls and gleaming floors

name: profuse
meaning: Something that is abundant or excessive
example: She was sweating profusely after running the marathon in the scorching heat

name: transitory
meaning: Lasting only a short time; temporary.
example: Temporary, or not lasting for a long time.

name: abrogate
meaning: Formally revoke a law or agreement
example: The board voted to abrogate the policy, recognizing its negative impact on employee morale

name: affluent
example: She comes from an affluent family and has never experienced financial hardship

name: altruism
example: His decision to donate a significant portion of his earnings to charity reflects his altruistic nature

name: anarchy
meaning: Absence of government, or lack of hierarchical authority
example: In the absence of a government, the country descended into anarchy, with widespread looting and violence

name: animosity
meaning: A strong dislike, or feeling hostile
example: There has been a long history of animosity between the two rival gangs

name: antiquated
example: The company still uses antiquated computer systems that are slow and inefficient

name: appreciable
example: There was an appreciable increase in sales after the marketing campaign

name: apprise
example: Please apprise me of any changes to the schedule

name: artless
meaning: Skill-less, or genuine without any hidden motive
example: The artless painting looked like it had been done by a child

name: augment
meaning: To increase, enlarge, or enhance something in size
example: She decided to augment her income by taking on a part-time job

name: avid
meaning: Extremely enthusiastic, eager, or passionate about something
example: He is an avid reader and can finish several books in a week

name: benign
example: The doctor assured the patient that the tumor was benign and not cancerous

name: boorish
meaning: Someone who behaves in a rude, insensitive, or uncultured manner
example: His boorish behavior at the dinner party embarrassed everyone

name: cerebral
meaning: Relating to the brain or the intellect
example: He is known for his cerebral approach to problem-solving, always relying on logic and analysis

name: conundrum
meaning: A confusing or difficult problem or situation
example: The company found itself in a conundrum when its primary supplier suddenly went out of business

name: conventional
example: He chose to pursue a conventional career path by becoming a lawyer

name: convoluted
example: The professor's explanation of the physics concept was so convoluted that the students struggled to grasp the fundamental principles

name: cumbersome
example: The antique furniture was beautiful but cumbersome to move due to its size and weight

name: decorum
meaning: Good manners, showing proper conduct, and maintaining a sense of dignity
example: In a job interview, it is essential to dress appropriately and speak with decorum to make a good impression

name: derivative
meaning: Unoriginal, or something that is obtained from another source
example: The movie received mixed reviews for its derivative plot and lack of originality

name: diminutive
meaning: Something that is small in size, stature, or significance
example: The puppy was adorable with its diminutive size and playful nature

name: discord
example: The team's poor communication resulted in discord and hindered their progress

name: disingenuous
meaning: Not sincere, or pretending to be honest
example: His apology came across as disingenuous, as he didn't show any genuine remorse for his actions

name: dissipate
example: She warned him not to dissipate his energy on unimportant tasks

name: elitist
example: The elitist art gallery only displayed works by established, high-profile artists

name: empiricism
meaning: The idea that all learning comes from only experience and observations
example: The scientist relied on empiricism to gather data through experiments and observations

name: enamored
meaning: Strongly infatuated with or captivated by someone or something
example: The child was enamored by the beautiful butterflies fluttering in the garden

name: enumerate
example: He was asked to enumerate his qualifications during the job interview

name: eponym
meaning: A name derived from other name
example: The city of Paris is an eponym derived from the name of its founding tribe, the Parisii

name: err
example: I apologize for my mistake. I erred in my calculations

name: erratic
example: The stock market showed erratic fluctuations throughout the day, making it difficult to predict trends

name: evasive
meaning: Avoiding commitment or self-revelation, especially by responding only indirectly.
example: His evasive behavior raised suspicions that he was hiding something

name: evenhanded
example: The judge demonstrated an evenhanded approach in delivering justice

name: excruciating
example: The athlete experienced excruciating pain after injuring his knee during the game

name: exorbitant
example: The hotel charges exorbitant prices during peak tourist season

name: feasible
meaning: Something that can be done, or achieved
example: The project manager presented a detailed plan outlining the steps and resources required to make the project feasible

name: frugal
meaning: Economical with their money and resources
example: She leads a frugal lifestyle, always searching for the best deals and avoiding unnecessary expenses

name: glean
example: He spent hours browsing online forums to glean advice on how to fix his computer

name: hamper
meaning: An obstacle that slows down , or restrict something
example: The heavy rain hampered our plans to go hiking in the mountains

name: hoodwink
example: The scam artist tried to hoodwink innocent people into giving away their personal information

name: iconoclastic
meaning: Someone or something that challenges or undermines established traditions, beliefs, or norms
example: The film's iconoclastic portrayal of a religious figure generated controversy and debate

name: imbibe
example: The students gathered in the library to imbibe knowledge from their textbooks

name: impending
meaning: About to happen or occur in the near future
example: The dark clouds and thunder signaled the impending storm

name: impervious
meaning: Unaffected or unable to be affected by something
example: The fortress was built with thick, impervious walls to withstand attacks

name: implicate
meaning: To convey, suggest, or indicate that someone or something is involved in a particular action
example: The document's contents strongly implicate the company in unethical practices

name: inarticulate
meaning: Unable to express thoughts, ideas, or feelings clearly
example: Under the pressure of public speaking, he became inarticulate and struggled to find the right words

name: insufferable
example: The heat in the room was insufferable, making it hard to breathe

name: intermittent
meaning: Something that occurs at irregular intervals
example: The internet connection was intermittent, causing frustration and disruptions during the online meeting

name: intimation
example: He gave me an intimation that she might resign from her position

name: irrevocable
meaning: Something that cannot be changed, or undone
example: His resignation letter made his departure from the company irrevocable

name: laudable
example: The team's laudable performance led them to victory in the championship

name: maladroit
example: Her maladroit dance moves drew laughter from the audience

name: malapropism
example: During her speech, she unintentionally used malapropisms, causing the audience to burst into laughter

name: malevolent
example: The villain in the story had a malevolent plan to destroy the city

name: martial
meaning: Relates to war, the military, or the armed forces
example: He received martial training and joined the army.

name: maverick
example: John is a maverick entrepreneur who always finds innovative ways to solve problems

name: miser
example: He was known as a miser who never spent money on anything other than absolute necessities

name: misogynist
example: The film was criticized for promoting a misogynistic narrative

name: nonchalant
example: His nonchalant response to the criticism surprised everyone

name: obtuse
example: Despite the clear explanation, he remained obtuse and couldn't understand the problem

name: ornate
example: The crown was an ornate piece of jewelry

name: palatable
example: The film had a palatable storyline and engaging characters that kept the audience entertained

name: peculiar
example: She has a peculiar habit of collecting vintage teacups and displaying them on her walls

name: peevish
example: She woke up in a peevish mood and snapped at everyone around her.

name: pellucid
example: Her presentation was pellucid, making complex concepts easy to grasp

name: placate
example: She offered a sincere apology to placate her upset friend

name: presumption
example: The professor questioned the student's argument, stating that it was based on unfounded presumptions

name: rash
example: His rash behavior often landed him in trouble with authorities

name: redress
example: The company is taking immediate steps to redress the customer's complaint

name: reservation
example: She expressed reservations about the proposed changes to the project

name: sanction
meaning: To approve(context: Positive); To impose penalties, restrictions(context: Negative)
example: The government issued sanctions against the company for violating environmental regulations

name: schadenfreude
example: He experienced a brief moment of schadenfreude upon learning that his coworker didn't get the promotion

name: sporadic
example: The town experienced sporadic power outages throughout the day due to the storm

name: thrifty
example: She is a thrifty shopper who always looks for sales and discounts

name: thwart
example: The security measures in place helped thwart the attempted robbery

name: unassailable
example: His argument was supported by such strong evidence that it seemed unassailable

name: unprepossessing
example: The building's exterior was rather unprepossessing, but its interior was surprisingly elegant

name: unviable
meaning: Something that is not feasible or practical
example: The proposed business model proved to be unviable due to high production costs

name: zenith
example: The company's success reached its zenith when it became the market leader

name: accolade
example: She received numerous accolades for her outstanding performance in the play

name: ample
example: The hotel provided amply sized rooms with comfortable beds and spacious bathrooms

name: assert
meaning: To state or declare something confidently and forcefully
example: She asserted her opinion during the meeting, explaining her reasons with conviction

name: badger
meaning: Repeatedly asking or annoying someone to do something
example: The salesperson wouldn't stop badgering me to buy the product, even after I said I wasn't interested

name: banality
example: The movie was a disappointing collection of banal plotlines and predictable characters

name: deceit
example: The politician's campaign was marked by deceitful tactics and false promises

name: decimation
example: The decimation of the rainforest has had devastating effects on biodiversity

name: demean
example: He used his position of power to demean and belittle his subordinates

name: docile
example: The dog was very docile and quickly learned commands during training

name: doleful
example: She sang a doleful song that brought tears to the audience's eyes

name: dupe
meaning: A person who has been deceived or tricked
example: She fell for the scam and became a dupe, losing a significant amount of money

name: duplicity
example: The company's CEO was known for his duplicity, often making promises he had no intention of keeping

name: hail
example: The new technology was hailed as a breakthrough in the field of medicine

name: haphazard
example: He packed his suitcase in a haphazard manner, throwing clothes and belongings in without any organization

name: implausible
example: The politician made an implausible promise during the campaign, raising doubts among the voters

name: indecorous
example: His indecorous jokes during the formal dinner offended many guests

name: jocular
example: The comedian's jocular performance had the audience roaring with laughter

name: jubilant
example: The team was jubilant after winning the championship

name: maintain
example: It is important to maintain a healthy diet and exercise regularly for physical well-being

name: meticulous
meaning: Very precise, careful & attention to details
example: She is known for her meticulous approach to project management, ensuring every aspect is thoroughly planned and executed

name: muted
example: She gave a muted response to the news of her promotion, not wanting to draw attention to herself

name: pacify
example: The government implemented measures to pacify the protesting citizens and address their concerns

name: perennial
example: The band's music has a timeless quality, making them a perennial favorite among music lovers

name: perturb
example: The loud noises from the construction site perturbed the residents, disrupting their peaceful environment

name: pester
meaning: To annoy or bother someone persistently
example: The child kept pestering his parents for a new toy

name: pith
example: In just a few pithy words, the author conveyed the entire theme of the novel

name: ploy
meaning: A cunning plan to take advantage
example: She used a ploy to distract her opponent and gain an advantage in the game

name: pragmatic
example: She took a pragmatic approach to the project, focusing on what would deliver the best outcomes within the given constraints

name: precedent
meaning: An earlier event or decision that serves as an example for future actions or judgments
example: The judge considered the legal precedent in similar cases before making a ruling

name: recapitulation
example: The professor provided a brief recapitulation of the lecture before concluding the class

name: row
example: The siblings constantly rowed over trivial matters

name: spartan
example: The marathon runner maintained a spartan lifestyle, prioritizing training

name: steadfast
example: She remained steadfast in her support for human rights, even in the face of opposition

name: swindle
example: The fake charity organization swindled people by claiming to support a noble cause while pocketing the donations

name: thoroughgoing
example: The company conducted a thoroughgoing analysis of its financial statements to identify areas of improvement

name: truncate
example: He had to truncate his speech due to time constraints

name: undermine
example: His constant criticism undermines her confidence and self-esteem

name: unruly
example: The police gathered to contain the unruly mob

name: veritable
example: He is a veritable genius

name: waver
example: She was wavering between two career options and couldn't decide which path to pursue

name: whimsical
example: The children's book was filled with whimsical illustrations and fantastical characters

name: aboveboard
example: Fair and aboveHe insisted on running his campaign aboveboard, without engaging in any underhanded tactics

name: aesthete
example: As an aesthete, she spends her weekends visiting art galleries and museums

name: apposite
example: The speaker's examples were apposite and helped clarify the complex concept

name: atavism
meaning: Throwback, or revival of a trait from a previous ancestral generation
example: The love for hunting and gathering food in the wilderness seemed like an atavistic instinct that couldn't be suppressed

name: begrudge
example: He begrudged his brother's new car and couldn't hide his jealousy

name: behoove
meaning: it is a duty or responsibility for someone to do something
example: As a responsible citizen, it behooves you to vote in the upcoming election

name: bridle
meaning: To restrain or control one's emotions, or actions
example: She tried to bridle her excitement upon hearing the good news

name: circumscribe
example: The fence circumscribes the perimeter of the property

name: conspicuous
meaning: Obvious, stands out or easy to notice
example: Her bright red hat made her quite conspicuous in the sea of people

name: convivial
example: He was known for his convivial nature and the ability to make everyone feel welcome

name: deign
meaning: To do something that one considers to be beneath one's dignity
example: The CEO rarely deigns to attend meetings with lower-level employees

name: demotic
meaning: Language that is relatable, and easily understood by the general public
example: The artist's paintings depicted scenes of everyday life in a demotic and relatable manner

name: desiccated
example: The desiccated corpse of the ancient mummy was carefully preserved in a museum

name: disinterested
example: The judge remained disinterested throughout the trial

name: dogmatic
meaning: Opinionated, or having strong opinions and refuse to accept that they may be wrong
example: The professor's lectures were often dogmatic, leaving little room for students to question or challenge ideas

name: envy
meaning: Longing desire for something that someone else possesses
example: He secretly envied his coworker's natural talent for public speaking

name: factitious
example: The painting was revealed to be factitious, created by a forger rather than the renowned artist

name: fastidious
example: She is known for her fastidious attention to detail, ensuring that every aspect of her work is flawless

name: fussy
example: She can be quite fussy about the arrangement of furniture in her house

name: goad
example: His friends goaded him into participating in the daring adventure

name: guffaw
example: The comedian's joke was so funny that the entire audience erupted in guffaws

name: ignoble
example: The politician's ignoble behavior tarnished his reputation and undermined public trust

name: immure
meaning: Enclose or confine someone or something within a space
example: The prisoners were immured in cramped cells, deprived of sunlight and fresh air

name: implacable
example: Despite numerous apologies, she remained implacable and refused to forgive him

name: intrepid
example: She showed her intrepid spirit by skydiving from an airplane

name: lionize
example: The public started to lionize the actor after his outstanding performance in the critically acclaimed film

name: magnanimous
example: The team captain showed a magnanimous spirit by praising the opposing team's performance

name: mollify
meaning: To calm, or appease someone's anger
example: He tried to mollify his upset friend by apologizing and promising to make things right

name: moot
example: The question of who would have won the race became moot when it was canceled due to bad weather

name: probity
meaning: Having strong moral principles and integrity
example: The judge's reputation for probity and fairness made her highly respected in the legal community

name: promulgate
example: The government will promulgate new regulations to address the issue of online privacy

name: proselytize
meaning: The act of attempting to convert someone to a particular religious, political, or ideological belief or system
example: The missionaries went door to door, seeking to proselytize people to their faith

name: pugnacious
example: The unruly student was known for their pugnacious behavior, often picking fights with classmates

name: quip
example: His quip about the situation had everyone laughing

name: restrain
example: The manager had to restrain the team's spending to stay within the budget

name: unconscionable
example: The landlord's demand for triple the rent was unconscionable

name: unstinting
meaning: Generous, or willingness to provide support, resources, etc
example: She showed unstinting support for her friends, always being there for them in times of need

name: vaunted
example: The company's vaunted product failed to deliver on its promises

name: vitality
meaning: The state of being strong, energetic, and full of life
example: Regular exercise and a healthy diet contribute to maintaining physical vitality

name: zeitgeist
meaning: Trend of a particular time period
example: The fashion industry often looks to the zeitgeist for inspiration in creating new trends

name: ambivalence
example: He experienced ambivalence when it came to choosing between two equally appealing options

name: ameliorate
example: The company took steps to ameliorate customer complaints by providing better customer service and product quality

name: apotheosis
example: The grand finale of the concert was an apotheosis of musical talent and creativity.

name: approbation
example: The talented artist received widespread approbation for her stunning paintings

name: appropriate
meaning: Suitable, or take something for one's own use, typically without the owner's permission
example: He decided to appropriate some of the company's funds for his personal use

name: arduous
meaning: Something that is difficult, or requires great effort
example: After months of arduous training, the athletes were ready for the intense competition

name: ascetic
example: The ascetic philosophy emphasized detachment from worldly desires and the pursuit of inner peace.

name: aspersion
meaning: Attack on the reputation or integrity of someone or something
example: It is unfair to cast aspersions on her loyalty simply because she holds a different opinion

name: assiduous
example: The team's success can be attributed to their assiduous efforts in researching, planning, and executing their projects

name: attenuate
meaning: To make something thinner, weaker, or less potent
example: The medication helped attenuate the symptoms of the illness, providing relief to the patient

name: austere
example: The office decor was kept austere, with minimalist furniture and neutral colors

name: aver
meaning: To assert or declare something with confidence or certainty
example: The witness averred that she saw the defendant at the scene of the crime

name: belie
meaning: To give a false impression, or to hide the truth
example: The gentle smile on her face belied the anger she was feeling

name: beneficent
example: The wealthy philanthropist donated a significant amount of money to the hospital, demonstrating his beneficent nature

name: besiege
example: The army besieged the enemy fortress, cutting off their supplies and launching constant attacks

name: besmirch
meaning: The act of damaging someone's reputation
example: It's unfair to besmirch someone's character without any evidence or proof

name: bilious
example: He woke up in a bilious mood, snapping at everyone around him

name: bombastic
meaning: Using words that are intended to impress people but do not sound sincere or do not express things very clearly
example: The politician's bombastic speeches were filled with empty promises and exaggerated claims

name: burgeon
example: The flowers in the garden began to burgeon with the arrival of spring

name: burnish
example: The craftsman skillfully burnished the silverware, giving it a mirror-like finish

name: buttress
example: She sought additional evidence to buttress her argument

name: cadaverous
example: The old man had a cadaverous face, with sunken eyes and hollow cheeks

name: cant
example: I could tell she was canting when she praised my work but had actually criticized it behind my back

name: conflate
example: The news article conflated two separate incidents, creating a false narrative

name: construe
example: I'm not sure how to construe her silence—does it mean she's upset or just lost in thought?

name: dilemma
meaning: A situation in which a difficult choice has to be made between two or more alternatives
example: I'm facing a dilemma between accepting the job offer with higher pay or staying at my current job, which I enjoy

name: dispensation
example: The boss gave me a dispensation from attending the meeting due to my illness

name: excoriate
example: The boss publicly excoriated the employee for their repeated mistakes in front of the entire team

name: grumpy
meaning: Who is easily annoyed, irritable, or in a bad mood
example: The teacher's grumpy attitude affected the whole class, making the atmosphere tense

name: jaundice
example: Shelly was jaundiced towards Oliva since she became the class president

name: junta
meaning: A small group, who seize power and establish a government
example: After overthrowing the president, the military junta took control of the country

name: perspicacious
meaning: Very insightful, or ability to observe and understand situations or ideas accurately and readily
example: The detective's perspicacious mind allowed her to solve the complex mystery in record time

name: pompous
example: She always spoke in a pompous manner, constantly boasting about her accomplishments

name: pontificate
meaning: Express one's opinions or judgments in an arrogant manner
example: She was known for her tendency to pontificate during meetings, dominating the conversation with her strong opinions

name: raconteur
example: At social gatherings, John always steals the spotlight as a talented raconteur, captivating everyone with his amusing tales

name: supercilious
example: The CEO's supercilious attitude towards his subordinates created a hostile work environment

name: acerbic
example: Most movie critics are acerbic towards summer blockbusters, often referring to them as garbage

name: balk
example: She balked at the idea of jumping off the high diving board due to her fear of heights

name: checkered
meaning: A situation or a person's past that is marked by a mixture of both favorable and unfavorable experiences or outcomes
example: He has a checkered past, with a history of both successes and failures

name: concise
meaning: Giving a lot of information clearly and in a few words
example: His presentation was concise, covering all the key points in just 10 minutes

name: dabbler
meaning: A person who engages in various activities or fields without fully committing to or specializing in any particular one
example: He's a dabbler who tries out different hobbies but never sticks with any of them for long

name: demur
example: When asked to work overtime, she demurred, citing prior commitments

name: dilettante
example: The company hired a dilettante to design their logo, resulting in a lackluster and unprofessional design

name: disabuse
meaning: Free someone from a misconception or false belief
example: The teacher worked hard to disabuse the students of their misconceptions about the scientific process

name: emulate
meaning: Match or surpass, typically by imitation
example: Most rulers wished to emulate Alexander the Great

name: errant
meaning: Straying, or deviating from the correct or intended course
example: The hiker took an errant path and ended up getting lost in the woods

name: implicit
meaning: Implied indirectly, without being directly expressed
example: The speaker made implicit references to past events without explicitly mentioning them

name: inert
meaning: Lacking the ability or strength to move
example: She lay inert in her bed

name: jejune
example: The movie was marketed as a gripping thriller, but it turned out to be a jejune and clichéd story

name: limpid
example: The lake's limpid waters reflected the vibrant colors of the surrounding trees

name: lugubrious
example: He had a lugubrious expression on his face as he delivered the bad news

name: pithy
example: She has a talent for crafting pithy slogans that stick in people's minds

name: plodding
example: The novel's plodding pace made it difficult to maintain interest in the story

name: poignant
example: The film had a poignant ending that left everyone in tears

name: staunch
example: Even in the face of criticism, she remained staunch in her beliefs and refused to compromise

name: stray
example: Try not to stray too far from the marked trail while hiking

name: superfluous
example: He included several superfluous details in his report, making it longer without providing any additional relevant information

name: umbrage
meaning: A feeling of anger or annoyance caused by something offensive.
example: He expressed umbrage when his colleague received credit for his idea

name: wanton
meaning: Extreme and showing no care at all
example: He engaged in wanton destruction, vandalizing property without reason

name: ascertain
meaning: Gathering information or evidence to establish the truth or accuracy of something
example: The scientists conducted experiments to ascertain the effects of the new drug on patients

name: bald
example: The report was a bald summary of the findings without providing any supporting evidence

name: capricious
meaning: Sudden change in attitude or behaviour; unpredictable
example: The movie star was capricious and difficult to please

name: contradict
meaning: To assert or express the opposite of something
example: The scientific findings contradict the commonly held belief

name: counterfactual
meaning: Something that is contrary to the facts or reality
example: In a counterfactual scenario, if I had won the lottery, I would have traveled the world

name: didactic
example: The film had a didactic message about the importance of environmental conservation

name: elicit
meaning: To draw out a response, information, or reaction from someone
example: The comedian's jokes were designed to elicit laughter from the audience

name: enervated
example: After working long hours without a break, he felt completely enervated and could barely muster the energy to walk

name: enigma
meaning: Something or someone puzzling, or mysterious
example: The disappearance of the ancient artifact remains an enigma to archaeologists

name: eulogy
meaning: A speech that praises someone, typically some who has recently died
example: The community gathered to hear the eulogies for the beloved mayor, celebrating his dedication and achievements

name: fallacious
example: His argument was built on fallacious assumptions

name: fickle
example: She's known for her fickle nature, as her interests and hobbies change every few months

name: flagging
example: The team's performance was flagging in the second half of the game

name: fledgling
example: The young bird took its first flight as a fledgling, flapping its wings nervously

name: gullible
example: She's so gullible that she falls for every online scam she encounters

name: hale
example: Even in his old age, he remained hale and hearty, with no signs of illness

name: husband
meaning: Manage or conserve resources carefully and efficiently
example: They need to husband their savings to afford their dream vacation

name: hypothesis
meaning: An idea or explanation for something that is based on known facts but has not yet been proved
example: The scientist formulated a hypothesis to explain the observed phenomenon

name: insensible
meaning: A state of being unaware, unresponsive, or lacking sensation
example: The hiker was so focused on his surroundings that he remained insensible to the pain in his blistered feet

name: lissome
example: The gymnast's lissome movements left the audience in awe of her agility and poise

name: lithe
example: The gymnast showcased her incredible strength and lithe athleticism during her routine

name: loathsome
example: The sight and smell of the garbage dump was truly loathsome

name: medley
example: The fashion show featured a medley of styles, showcasing both modern and vintage designs

name: melange
example: The artist created a melange of colors on the canvas, blending vibrant hues with subtle tones

name: misanthrope
meaning: One who hates the human race
example: Sarah has become quite a misanthrope in her later years, preferring the company of her books over social gatherings

name: mitigate
meaning: To make something less severe, intense, or harmful
example: Planting trees around the neighborhood can help mitigate the effects of air pollution

name: novice
example: The company hired a team of experts to train the novices and teach them the fundamentals of sale

name: overt
example: The politician's overt support for the bill was evident in his public speeches

name: paean
meaning: A chant or song to celebrate or honor
example: The crowd erupted in a joyous paean as their team scored the winning goal

name: panacea
meaning: A remedy or solution that is believed to cure all problems
example: The new drug was hailed as a panacea for various health conditions, promising to provide relief for a wide range of symptoms

name: paucity
example: There is a paucity of job opportunities in the current economic climate

name: peddle
example: The company hired a team of salespeople to peddle their new product to potential customers

name: philanthropic
meaning: Promotes the welfare of others through charitable donations, or volunteer work
example: The billionaire's philanthropic efforts have greatly impacted communities around the world

name: pioneer
meaning: A person who is one of the first people to do something
example: Marie Curie was a pioneering scientist who made groundbreaking discoveries in the field of radioactivity

name: polemic
meaning: A piece of writing or a speech in which a person strongly attacks or defends a particular opinion, person, idea, or set of beliefs
example: The professor delivered a polemic against the prevailing theories in the field, challenging their validity and offering alternative perspectives

name: precipitate
meaning: To make something happen suddenly and quickly
example: His reckless actions precipitated a chain reaction of consequence

name: qualified
meaning: Meeting the standards, requirements, and training for a position
example: She is a highly qualified candidate for the job, with a relevant degree and several years of experience

name: recant
example: After being pressured by the authorities, the politician was forced to recant his controversial statement

name: refute
meaning: To prove something to be false
example: The scientist was able to refute the theory by conducting rigorous experiments that contradicted its predictions

name: relegate
meaning: Assigning someone or something to a lower position
example: After his poor performance, he was relegated to a bench role on the team

name: rhetorical
meaning: The effective use of language or speech for persuasion or communication
example: The politician used a rhetorical question to engage the audience and make them think about the issue at hand.

name: sage
example: The elderly man was regarded as a sage in the community, sought after for his wise advice and guidance

name: skeptic
meaning: A skeptic is a person who doesn't believe something is true unless they see evidence
example: The detective approached the case with a skeptic's eye, considering all possible explanations and not jumping to conclusions

name: specious
meaning: Appears to be true, but is actually false
example: The politician's specious promises during the campaign won over many voters, but failed to materialize once in office

name: steward
meaning: Who is responsible for managing and overseeing
example: As the head steward of the hotel, she ensured that guests had a pleasant stay and addressed any concerns or requests

name: stigma
meaning: A mark of shame, disgrace, or social disapproval
example: The transgender community has long fought against the stigma and discrimination they face on a daily basis

name: tacit
example: His silence was a tacit admission of guilt

name: tirade
meaning: A long, angry speech of criticism or accusation
example: After receiving a low grade on his paper, the student went on a tirade, accusing the professor of unfairness and incompetence

name: torpid
example: The bear entered a torpid state during the winter months, hibernating in its den

name: trite
example: The movie's plot was trite and predictable, following the same formula as many other romantic comedies

name: upend
example: The unexpected turn of events upended the entire plan

name: vacillating
example: The committee's vacillating approach to the issue led to delays in making a decision

name: verbose
meaning: Someone who uses more words than necessary
example: Instead of getting to the point, the politician's speech was filled with verbose and convoluted language

name: viable
example: The company presented a viable business plan that convinced investors to provide funding

name: volatile
meaning: Likely to change rapidly and unpredictably
example: The stock market is highly volatile, with prices fluctuating dramatically from one day to the next

name: alibi
meaning: Evidence or a statement that proves a person was elsewhere at the time a crime was committed
example: The defendant presented multiple witnesses who testified to his alibi, proving that he was out of town when the robbery took place

name: compendium
meaning: A comprehensive collection of information on a particular subject.
example: The encyclopedia is a comprehensive compendium of human history

name: cosmology
meaning: Study of the origin, structure, and evolution of the universe
example: Cosmology is a branch of astronomy that seeks to understand the origins and composition of the universe

name: craven
example: The craven soldier deserted his post during the battle, leaving his comrades behind

name: discrete
example: Each item in the collection is a discrete entity with its own unique characteristics

name: homogeneous
example: The solution should be mixed thoroughly until it becomes homogeneous, with no visible variations in color or texture

name: impassive
example: Despite the tragic news, she remained impassive and didn't show any outward signs of distress

name: indeterminate
example: The future of the project remains indeterminate, as there are still many variables to consider

name: indifferent
example: She was completely indifferent to the outcome of the game, as she had no interest in sports

name: intrigue
example: The unique painting style of the artist intrigued art critics and collectors alike

name: laconic
example: His responses during the interview were laconic, providing just enough information without going into unnecessary details

name: levity
example: She approached the situation with levity, finding humor in even the most challenging circumstances

name: oscillate
example: Her feelings for him oscillated between love and hate, never quite settling on one

name: partisan
meaning: One sided, or committed to a party, cause, or person
example: The newspaper article was clearly written by a partisan journalist, favoring one side of the debate

name: pathological
meaning: Extreme deviation from the normal or expected
example: The company's financial records revealed a pattern of pathological dishonesty and fraud

name: piety
example: The elderly woman expressed her piety by attending daily prayers at the local mosque

name: plasticity
example: Children have a higher level of plasticity, making it easier for them to learn new skills

name: substantiate
meaning: To provide evidence, support, or proof for something
example: The scientist conducted experiments to substantiate her hypothesis

name: tangential
example: Her comment was interesting but somewhat tangential to the overall conversation

name: tractable
example: The dog is very tractable and responds well to training commands

name: untenable
example: His argument was quickly proven untenable when presented with solid evidence to the contrary

name: vapid
meaning: Offering nothing that is stimulating or challenging, making it boring
example: The novel had promising cover art, but its contents turned out to be vapid and uninspiring

name: zealot
meaning: A person who has very strong opinions about something, and tries to make other people have them too
example: He was a religious zealot, tirelessly preaching and advocating for his faith

name: alienate
example: His rude behavior and offensive remarks alienated his coworkers, making it difficult for him to work effectively in a team

name: apologist
meaning: Someone who defends a particular idea or cause
example: The politician's speech was seen as that of an apologist, as he attempted to justify the controversial actions of his party

name: bemuse
example: The magician's tricks were so intricate and skillful that they completely bemused the audience

name: bogus
example: The company was accused of selling bogus weight loss supplements that had no scientific evidence to support their claims

name: boon
example: The discovery of a new energy source was a boon for the country's economy

name: brandish
meaning: To wave something in the air in a threatening or excited way
example: The knight brandished his sword, ready to defend himself against the enemy

name: calamitous
example: The earthquake had a calamitous impact on the city, leaving thousands homeless and causing widespread destruction

name: callous
example: Despite her friend's loss, she made a callous remark about it

name: diffuse
example: The light in the room was diffuse, creating a soft and gentle ambiance

name: elegy
meaning: A poem or a song that expresses sorrow
example: The poet composed a beautiful elegy to honor his late father

name: endemic
meaning: Confined to a particular region or context
example: Malaria is endemic in certain tropical regions of Africa, where the disease is consistently present and widespread

name: exigency
example: The government declared a state of emergency in response to the public health exigency caused by the outbreak

name: exponential
meaning: Something that grows or increases at an accelerating rate
example: The population of the city has experienced exponential growth over the past decade

name: guileless
example: The child's guileless smile brightened the room and warmed everyone's hearts

name: homily
meaning: A lecture on moral or religious theme
example: The priest delivered an inspiring homily on forgiveness during Sunday's church service

name: lax
example: The teacher was criticized for being too lax with grading assignments

name: problematic
meaning: Existence of issues, challenges, or concerns
example: The company's financial situation is problematic, with mounting debts and declining revenues

name: profound
meaning: Deep, significant, or having great depth of meaning
example: The speaker delivered a profound speech that left the audience deeply moved and inspired

name: prolific
example: J.K. Rowling is known for being a prolific author, having written numerous bestselling books

name: proscribe
example: The law proscribes driving a car while intoxicated

name: reprobate
example: The judge declared the defendant to be a reprobate and sentenced him to life in prison

name: repudiate
example: The politician was quick to repudiate the accusations of corruption and maintained his innocence

name: rescind
example: The board voted to rescind the previous resolution due to new information

name: resolution
example: She made a resolution to exercise every day and stick to a healthy diet

name: resolve
example: Despite facing numerous setbacks, he remained resolved to achieve his goals

name: stipulate
meaning: Condition or requirement that is explicitly stated
example: The rules of the competition stipulate that participants must be at least 18 years old

name: synoptic
example: The professor provided a synoptic view of the historical events leading up to the war

name: taciturn
example: Trying to have a conversation with Mark was challenging due to his taciturn responses, as he preferred to keep to himself

name: treacherous
example: Be careful when dealing with him, as he has a treacherous nature and is known for betraying others

name: unwieldy
meaning: Difficult to handle, manage, or use
example: The old television set was so large and heavy that it became increasingly unwieldy to move around

name: viscous
example: The honey was so viscous that it took a while for it to pour out of the jar

name: vitiate
example: A single error in the calculation can vitiate the entire experiment

name: astonish
meaning: To surprise or impress someone greatly
example: The magician's incredible trick left the audience astonished and speechless

name: astound
meaning: To greatly surprise or shock someone
example: The students' scientific discovery astounded their teachers, as it challenged long-held theories in the field

name: befriend
meaning: To make friend by offering help or support
example: She decided to befriend her new neighbor by inviting her over for coffee

name: beguile
meaning: To deceive or charm someone in a cunning or deceptive manner
example: The magician's tricks beguiled the audience and left them in awe

name: beholden
meaning: Indebted to someone, typically due to a favor or kindness they have done for you
example: The politician felt beholden to the voters who elected him and worked hard to fulfill their expectations

name: chronology
meaning: Arrangement or ordering of events in the order they occurred
example: The detective used the chronology of phone calls to piece together the suspect's movements

name: elate
example: Winning the championship elated the entire team

name: explicit
meaning: Something that is clearly and directly stated or expressed
example: The instructions were explicit, outlining each step in detail

name: factual
meaning: Something that is based on facts
example: Her argument was based on factual data and statistical analysis

name: hector
example: The older boys hector the younger kids on the playground, making them feel scared and inferior

name: inveigle
example: The salesman tried to inveigle the customer into buying an expensive product by offering exaggerated promises and discounts

name: perplexed
example: Sarah looked perplexed when she couldn't find her keys and couldn't remember where she had put them

name: precarious
example: The hiker found himself in a precarious position when he lost his way and darkness began to fall

name: presumptuous
meaning: Showing too much confidence and not enough respect
example: She had the presumptuousness to assume that she would automatically be given the promotion

name: recondite
example: The professor's lecture on quantum physics was filled with recondite concepts that left most of the students perplexed

name: refractory
example: The refractory child refused to obey his parents' instructions

name: reproach
meaning: To express disapproval or disappointment in one's actions
example: She reproached him for his careless behavior

name: supplement
example: I take vitamin supplements to ensure I'm getting all the necessary nutrients

name: tactless
example: The boss's tactless remarks during the meeting offended several employees

name: vindicate
example: The evidence presented in court vindicated the defendant, proving their innocence

name: wilful
example: Despite the warnings, he made a wilful decision to go ahead with the risky investment

name: witty
example: She always has a witty comeback for every situation

name: acute
example: The region is experiencing an acute water shortage due to prolonged drought

name: adroit
example: The adroit surgeon successfully performed the complex procedure with precision and speed

name: coda
meaning: A concluding event, remark, or section
example: His new novel is a kind of coda to his previous books

name: delineate
example: The architect used a blueprint to delineate the exact dimensions and layout of the building

name: dismiss
example: The manager dismissed the proposal as impractical and unrealistic

name: ideological
meaning: Based on or relating to a particular set of ideas or beliefs
example: The newspaper article criticized the government's decision, arguing that it was driven by ideological bias rather than practical considerations

name: igneous
example: The geothermal activity in the region is a result of the underlying igneous activity

name: ingenuous
example: She told her story with such ingenuousness that it was impossible not to believe her

name: irresolute
example: The team's performance suffered due to the coach's irresolute leadership and inability to make decisive changes

name: obviate
example: The new software update includes several bug fixes that obviate the need for manual workarounds

name: occlude
example: The fallen tree branches occlude the path, making it difficult for hikers to proceed

name: officious
example: The officious neighbor always interferes in our affairs, offering unsolicited advice on how to run our household

name: precursor
meaning: Something that happened or existed before another thing
example: The artist's early sketches were precursors to her later masterpieces

name: prevaricate
example: The politician was known to prevaricate when confronted with difficult questions during interviews

name: propensity
meaning: A strong natural tendency to do something
example: The team's star player has a propensity for scoring goals in critical moments of the game

name: prosaic
example: The movie failed to capture the audience's attention with its prosaic plot and predictable storyline

name: reverence
meaning: Respect, admiration, or awe for someone
example: The students greeted their teacher with reverence as they entered the classroom

name: sabotage
example: The labor union threatened to sabotage the production process if their demands were not met

name: salubrious
example: Eating a balanced diet and exercising regularly are essential for maintaining a salubrious lifestyle

name: salutary
example: The feedback she received from her supervisor was salutary, as it helped her identify areas for improvement

name: selfless
example: The selfless teacher stayed late every day to provide extra help to struggling students

name: sensual
example: That massage was a very sensual experience!

name: sensuous
meaning: Providing pleasure or gratification to the senses
example: The garden was filled with the sensuous fragrance of blooming flowers, enveloping visitors in a delightful scent

name: shrewd
meaning: Clever in their thinking and decision-making
example: Despite his young age, the shrewd businessman was able to negotiate a favorable deal

name: slack
example: The team's performance was affected by a slack defense

name: stolid
example: Despite the chaos and commotion around him, John remained stolid and composed

name: supersede
example: The new digital technology has superseded the traditional analog system

name: tortuous
example: The author's writing style was admired for its rich, detailed, and somewhat tortuous descriptions

name: venerate
meaning: To honor or have great respect for a person or thing
example: The people of the village venerate their local religious leader for his wisdom and guidance

name: veracious
